pros: good culture and great location
cons: There is nothing to complain

review_title: Poor management, low salary, lots of drama
job_title: Associate Director of Enrollment in London, England
pros: Friendly environment (careful of whom you speak to) Fun For young people, lots of events and food and drinks Nice offices
cons: - Repetitive tasks mostly due to a very segmented process, you only get to work on a small aspect of the enrollment process - Very very low salaries - No career perspective - No flexible hours : 9am to 7pm - No HR department ?? - Huge turnover - Poor management and abuse from Senior management who will treat you like you are worthless if you do not reach the numbers depsite them not training you properly, you have 0 training here, you are on your own. -A lot of drama and rumors spread around the office, this is a very political environment with a lot of non factual statements -Emotional rollercoaster - No profesionalism, toxic culture

pros: Good people, friendly atmosphere, nice location
cons: slightly reactive environment, not well organised at times

review_title: Poor leadership, low salaries and high staff turnover
pros: Nice offices Opportunities to part take in an MBA
cons: - Leadership is very short sighted, the preach a linear management structure with no hierarchy but certainly do not act in such a manner - Management does not care about the career progression of their teams which results in the high level of turnover - Team morale is often low - Salaries are low, increases are dismal and the bonus structure is non existent. Senior leadership gets paid a whack but the rest of the staff get very little by way of compensation (and benefits) - Toxic culture

pros: flexible hours and good community
cons: repetitive tasks and lack of avalible space to work

review_title: Terrible work culture and low salary
pros: Nice office, good location, nice people in overall EF company.
cons: No guidance, no empathy, bad leadership, no structure.

job_title: Digital Marketing Coordinator in Chelsea, England
pros: Some of the best people you'll work with Good work environment Annual trips abroad
cons: Significant salary raises are very rare for most people Almost impossible to move up in the company Salaries are very low in comparison to other companies

review_title: Nice benefits but poor salary and department structure
pros: Nice benefits include after-work activities and gym access
cons: Poor salary and department structure

pros: - The staff population reflects the same diversity found in the student body. - There's a sense of community and warmth in the teams/offices. - You feel confident to bring your whole self to work. - Flexible work-from-home/office days.
cons: - Due to the fast-paced environment, it can feel unorganized. - Have to be comfortable with last-minute changes.

job_title: Head of Student Services in London, England
pros: Great colleagues, great atmosphere, lots of great events
cons: Management is not the best… there is no HR which means there is no structure

pros: Absolutely great culture in the marketing team, it's really nice to be part of this group!
cons: I wish there would be more employee perks.

job_title: Director of Enrollment in London, England
pros: Amazing people , Very good working environment . Agile and forward thinking
cons: favouritism, no work life balance, senior management looking out for themselves and are able to put the blame on you for things. no transperancy in salaries or pay scales.

review_title: Great community and core values, low Salary/progression opportunities
pros: The community, team, and culture of the company. Employees have a space to feel at home. the office in London has many facilities.
cons: Salary does not reflect the employee's responsibilities, the career progression is limited and there isn't a solid benefits scheme.

pros: Love working here and the best is the global mindset!
cons: Long hours and sometimes no time for anything else

review_title: Good beginner job with dramatic teams
pros: international team, a lot of responsibilities
cons: micromanagement, dramatic moments at the office

job_title: Director of Enrollment in London, England
pros: - Travelling internationally - fun environment
cons: - Poor management - Low salaries - No feedback or development

pros:
- fun place to work for young people 
- a lot of activities at work and outside working hours
cons:
- competitive 
- at some point you feel like you have no life outside work as there are so many drinks, parties etc organised within organisation outside working hours that you it makes you feel like the company sucks you in (your time in and out of work, and you go because of fear or missing)

job_title: Digital Outreach Coordinator in London, England
pros: The environment was extremely welcoming, we got the choice when we got to go to the office. The managers took the time to get to know you. As a first office to work in it was an amazing experience!
cons: I found the lack of set hours as a part-time employee challenging but I achieved my targets nonetheless. It's difficult to actually be part-time when you need to maintain relationships / communication with potential leads. I liked the flexibility nonetheless.

pros: good pay, good atmosphere and people
cons: long hours, no food on shift

pros: awesome office, very diverse group of people, very approachable management style

job_title: Events Marketing Manager in London, England
pros: Great Social Environment with lots of perks around office and London
cons: Lack of Leadership Skills in Managers

pros: -good environment, nice work balance
cons: -flexibility not always present in concrete terms

review_title: Long hours and low pay for a private university
pros: Private medical insurance for permanent staff; snazzy, modern work environment; free coffee, milk and snacks. Sometimes your Manager will order you a free meal here and there, which is a nice perk.
cons:
The working hours (9am-6pm) are unusually long for the higher education sector generally in the UK, and this uplift in hours is not reflected in employee salaries, which pale in comparison to other public UK Universities... This is counterintuitive, as Hult is a private, international university which charges its students astronomical fees. 

From my experience there is also an expectation that employees will work overtime with no Time Off In Lieu (TOIL), which seems exploitative, especially for the higher education sector.

review_title: Lovely environment and workspace, inspiring colleagues and managers.
job_title: Director of Enrollment in London, England
pros: Office location and workspace, with gym and bike park space. Innovative environment, full of diversity. Colleagues and Managers are friendly and lively, and always ready to help. Staff training workshops are frequent, as well as networking events.
cons: Salaries, very fast peace between deadlines.

review_title: Not a good company to work for
pros: Nice office in London located in west London
cons: The team in London was very competitive and not friendly at all. There is a bit micromanagement problem in this company where employees can’t work peacefully. Managers are always looking over your shoulder. The office is kinda cute but the company is only looking to get students in and pay very high fees.

review_title: They only care about their alumni that work with them at the moment
job_title: Recruitment of Students in London, England
pros: Better than being jobless I guess. They organize good events though and it is fun.
cons:
Salaries does not go up at all unless you are a former student, but not everyone can afford to study with them. You only get promotion if you studie3d with them, and they tell you like that like pretending their students are the best.
After corona they fired every worker that was placed in furlough.

review_title: Used to keep HULT alumni employed
pros: some of the people who work there are nice
cons: It is very repetitive, spend a lot of time on the phone with students who have no idea why you are calling them and are not interested. It is a very unfair and toxic work environment as the only people who progress are HULT Students and Alumni! They usually get double of the salary other people would get and even if they do not reach their target, they are kept employed as they studied at HULT and therefore it looks good for the university's employment statistics. You work on Saturdays. Senior management would lie to your face as they don't know how to have a conversation and are scared of confrontation.

pros: I really enjoy working here
cons: I don’t see any cons

job_title: Regional Sales Director in London, England
pros: Culture, People, Open, Diverse, Agile
cons: Compensation, Senior Management, Work Life Balance

review_title: Great office environment, good social life and community, not great pay
pros: Great office environment, good social life and community
cons: Pay could be better, and bonus scheme would be good

job_title: Senior Project Manager in London, England
pros: Agile environment flexible working, team work
cons: No methodology, pay system grading

pros: Diversity, inclusion, rewarding, remuneration, growth
cons: none, none, none, none, none

pros: Nice people, OK travel perks, standard PTO
cons: Terrible pay, difficult to move up the ladder

review_title: Good to work for the start of your professional career
job_title: Corporate Relations Executive in London, England
pros: Inclusive and multicultural culture / environment
cons: Career progression and employees rewarding system

review_title: A generally terrible place to work - globally.
job_title: Associate Director of Recruiting in London, England
pros: Opportunity to work with and interact with different departments and campuses.  If you find the right team than it is a good place to work but only if you accept that your work will be rarely appreciated.  The only great work that Hult was able to do was get Hult Prize working - even after first both resisting or supporting it in it's early stages. Please don't ruin it.
cons:
More focus on Sales and Marketing than on anything else. It can be justified as Hult is in a competitive place 
Hypocrisy - teaching students about valuable skills to have in the future work place but failing to practice and build a culture around the same internally. Level of nepotism is astonishing but not surprising as Hult is owned and operated as part of a larger family business. Zero room for personal development or growth - long job titles have very little meaning with the person having pretty much the same job or being a glorified junior member of their own team. Moving targets and lack of accountability especially with senior management create a toxic culture of mistrust and lack of direction.

job_title: Associate Director of Enrollment in London, England
pros: Environment, young team, benefits, parties and trips
cons: No HR department at all

job_title: Director of Recruiting in London, England
pros: Office drinks, office atmosphere, traveling
cons:
They make you work long hours, nothing to learn in this company, they are called a non profit business school. The reality is that they have another company called Hult Consultancy Services or something like that where they have all the money they make from this huuuuuge business. People who work there are extremely nice, however, you see some people with no education being managers, or not much experience being directors. Then you see people with MBA working as telesales with hourly rates. At the end of their financial year, if you did't hit your target, you are fired. People leave all the time.

The recruiting of students is awful. Basically anyone can be accepted. They just need to pay a lot of money for a program that is not even accredited. Does the school help you find a job? Of course not! You already paid them, they are too busy trying to recruit more students, they don't have time to help you find a job.

pros:
Very fast paced environment where your colleagues become your friends, so work and social life become mixed. 

It is a love/hate culture. You will either love it. Or you will hate it. I don't know anyone who is only "OK". 

People who love Hult like the hard-work culture, the flexibility, the high aspirations, the diversity of the workplace and the fast pace to decision making.

People who hate Hult do not like the fact that it is expected you work so hard (particularly in recruiting), that the management are quick to fire people, and the amount of travel required.  

I suspect most of the people giving very negative comments on this board were fired.
cons:
Fit in or out culture that demands everything of people and is quick to discard them if the performance is not up to expectations. You need to be ok with the fluidity because it is likely you will have many different bosses through firing, promotion, relocation etc.

Benefits should be reviewed. Whilst salaries are competitive the benefits are behind that of alternate employers.

review_title: Fast Pace and Unique Place to Work
job_title: Associate Director of Recruiting in London, England
pros: Starting a job at Hult was a life-changing experience for me. You can begin from the lowest level and climb up if you bring consistent results and have ideas. If you are entrepreneurial and know how to sell your ideas, you can achieve a lot in the company. The atmosphere is very free spirited, senior management is approachable. Well performing staff has access to different education and talent development schemes. There is no company I know of where all staff has so many opportunities to travel internationally. There is a private insurance and pension scheme. The office in London is shared with EF  and has beautiful interior design. There is a free gym open to all staff.
cons: Company culture is very strong and it not everyone fits into it well. The atmosphere is quite hectic, a lot of changes happen and not always they are well communicated. New people often find themselves in a sink or swim situation which is also a test whether the company is really a fit for them.

review_title: Fast paced and supportive work environment
pros: I took a big risk on Hult and it is so far paying off. I work in a great team where we have fun and interesting work and are fully supported by a very intelligent manager. The staff are hugely international so everyone is warm and welcoming and you can visit any Hult office in the world and it feels like you are in your usual spot. They pay well for the right people, there is a free gym onsite as well as paying for your phone bill and providing free private health insurance. It is a work hard, play hard culture and there is room to grow.
cons: Not all teams are fortunate to have great managers and as others have said, decisions are made quickly and not always well communicated. The office hours are long and the pressure to perform is always present.

pros: Fast paced, multicultural, stimulating, welcoming culture - which is fostered by staff who are focused on making a marked difference to all our students. There are significant development opportunities for those who seek them and a DNA that strives for continuous development...plus there is always another happy hour just round the corner.
cons: It is a people business and people can be unpredictable - especially young adults. There is always pressure to meet their needs, whilst working within our framework as an education provider. There has also been, at times, the reliance of short term fixes rather than looking to embed processes which would ensure long term games.

review_title: No structure and no progression.Stay away!
pros:
-Drinks in the kitchen
-Few nice people
-Campus Locations
I can't think about any other pros.
cons: Stay away if you can! Do not drag yourself into this mess and do not believe any positive reviews as it is all fake. The company has no structure. They get rid of managers and make the teams to work hard with nothing in return. They are not interested in your promotion or development. Most of the teams are demotivated and you won't be welcomed properly. The salaries are very low, the benefits are poor and you will just get stuck at the same level forever with nothing in return. The company clearly has their favorites (those people who suck up to management or somehow related to them) If you are not one of the favorites, do stay away!  There is no future for hard working people in this company. FYI very high turnover of staff ( at least 4-5 people per month are leaving)

pros: Very multicultural team of young people to work with. Average age of late 20s early 30s. Very relaxed environment and quite fast paced too.  A lot of social events and investment in team building. Very good starting to point for the world of Immigration and a lot of hands-on training.
cons: Really stressful and long hours during the summer months leading up to the beginning of the next academic year. Work after a few months seems tedious and very repetitive. Management (un)intentionally creating a very competitive environment.

review_title: Steep learning curve at the beginning then no further opportunities to grow
job_title: Director of Recruiting in London, England
pros:
- (mostly) international, young team
- lots of travelling (including some nice incentive trips)
- innovative solutions in running a business school
- beautiful offices in great locations
cons:
- no HR department
- protectionism (hiring friends and relatives who are unqualified to do the job, and then not sacking them)
- no training, no induction
- incompetent managers, even in top management
- open racism and sexism from some of the colleagues and managers but there is no one to report these issues to
- no honest feedback from supervisors and no willingness to grow their people
- people played against each other by managers
- huge variations between salaries of people officially working on the same level
- extreme pressure to perform and no job security

pros: Inspiring to work for a company that is trying to be the best it can be. Constantly changing and trying to do better. And willing to take risks in that process. Great to have similar minded colleagues all over the world. Very close knit, despite the geographic distances. And plenty of opportunity to travel.
cons: Very, very hard work. All senior managers are workaholics. And there is unlimited number of things to get on with, which at times can be very stressful. There is often not time to even pause to think since things are constantly changing and you are always challenged. Sometime dauntingly so.

pros: Very fun company to work for! A lot of young people with a lot of energy. Responsibility is given to new employees at a very early stage and the whole atmosphere is extremely entrepreneurial even though it is a rather large company. Great company culture. Super international and global workplace, with elegant, modern offices all around the world and with staff from literally almost every country on earth. A lot of opportunity to grow within the company.
cons: Wages seem to be slightly below industry averages and working hours are often longer. However this is often compensated by making the workplace a nice environment to be in.

pros: Super entrepreneurial spirit all around. A great place to develop your ideas within the mission and vision of the company.  Being a flat company, it also allows you to freely express your ideas and and test them in the real world. You get to develop also the skills working in an international environment since your colleagues come from many nationalities. Excellent if you are looking into relocating within the company since there are offices literally around the globe.
cons: Work Life Balance. However, it really depends up to you to be effective and productive at work. I guess it is a test on how you can prioritize your tasks and excel in time management. I am still working on it though

pros: Fair pay for the role, travel opportunities, pretty office
cons: Get used to office politics, your manager will throw you under the bus to get a head. Terrible working hours, NO work life balance, expect your work to be your life. If you aren't at 150% happy to be there every day, loving selling executive education not the place for you. They are more focused on meeting their individual sales targets than what is in the best interest for the student.

pros:
-Very relaxed environment!
- Some nice people ( unfortunetly they all leave very soon)
- Many staff events, leaving drinks etc.
cons: This company is Swedish, so the first thing i would like to point out that if you are not Swedish , you do not have many opportunities for progression. However, senior management really appreciates people who "suck up" to get a promotion. They do not care about dedicated and talented people who has beenwith a company for a long time. They are not afraid to loose them. Also, if they loose someone, they do not replace them. Very high turnover of staff!Very unprofessional environment! Some teams do not even have a manager.

job_title: Associate Director of Recruiting in London, England
pros:
I love working at Hult because it is always challenging me and keeping me on my toes. Things are always changing, always new and I am never bored. The job has a lot of elements to it, so you are never doing the same thing for a huge amount of time, and your day is so full it flies by! For some people this might not be ideal, but I have a lot of energy and it keeps me super busy, which is great.

The office culture is amazing. It is super young, energetic and positive. There is always some kind of incentive and we have lots of perks. There is a really big focus on work hard, play hard. Sometimes we have to work long hours and weekends, but management recognize us and treat us to make up for it. There is quite a part culture, so if you want a glass of wine after a long day, there won't be a lack of company! The people I work with are super nice and friendly and I can definitely say that I have made some really good friends here.

The management really look out for you and I do feel very comfortable with them. I can talk to them about anything, and they do aim in getting the best from you, so there is a lot of room to improve yourself, succeed and move up in the company. I do think there are many opportunities within Hult, and if you work hard you will be given those opportunities.

The travelling aspect of the job, of course, is a great pro. As a people person I prefer to meet people face to face so the travelling really allows me to meet my candidates and feel more connected to my job.

There is not a lot of micro managing which is great, I like that I am trusted to do my job and no one is looking over my shoulder every 5 minutes.
cons:
The hours can be long and you will have to work weekends so sometimes you do get the feeling that the job takes over. It's really necessary to make sure you keep a good work/life balance, otherwise you will basically be surrounded by work 24/7. A key thing is to avoid the emails and work system outside of work!

When I started there was very little training if any at all, and although since then there has been a huge improvement, it's something that could still be worked on. New staff need to be taught and should have their expectations managed. Hult is very different to any other company and it can be a real shock for those coming in from outside to be thrown head first into the role and the culture.

Although change is good overall, sometimes there can be a lot of it. Although for me personally this is not that big of an issue, for the team it can sometimes set things back when a key member leaves or moves on. A good "bounce back" attitude is needed.

job_title: Student Recruitment Coordinator in London, England
pros: Lovely environment, lots of young people, events and free lunches/dinners sometimes.
cons:
The company has a ridiculously high turnover rate and there are clear reasons for it. The role itself is a glorified cold caller. No progression for growth "unless an opportunity arises" ie if someone leaves. You will be making close to 80-100 calls a day, most of which are bad leads they get from things like GoogleAds. Plenty of Voicemails. They say its not cold calling, but it essentially is.

Salary is terrible. Head office in the middle of sloane square, one of the poshest parts of London, yet paying staff as low as 16k a year. Cost of living in London is high so expect to live paycheck to paycheck. I'd rather have more money in my pocket than management spending lots of money on lunches/dinners. Just give your employees slightly more money.

Instead of a standard contract where you are paid a certain amount each month, you end up filling in a timesheet every day to show how many hours you have worked. You will not be paid for lunch either. Shows a lack of commitment to your staff if you dont even offer them proper security. If you are ill and dont work for 1 week - you wont get paid for the week. This is not regarding any probationary period - it is like this even after 6 months.

In the end, you probably get 16k on a full time basis if you work your socks off. Long hours, I used to start 10:30PM -- 7:30PM so it does affect your social life.

Advice to Employees: Don't try so hard. Have fun and take advantage of the buzzing social element of Hult.

review_title: Hult is an amazing place to work
job_title: Career Development Manager in London, England
pros:
Personally speaking, I feel Hult has a really strong culture which encourages innovative solutions to be implemented rapidly where the student is placed at the very heart of what we do. The drive to ensure students are happy and achieve their goals is boundless and I love that focus. 

We never spend ages in meetings talking about stuff which we might do in a few years time, we are much more fast moving than that, thank goodness.

I can see how this might look like I have been asked to write this but I genuinely love working for Hult, I love my job and I feel really engaged in the future of the school. For me, it is a perfect fit. I have been working here a few years now and strongly feel it matches the way I like to work and provides me with a good vehicle for my unusual range of talents and experience.
cons:
Hult has a very special culture and it really is not suitable for everyone. Just because it's education, don't imagine you will just be able to fit in and work here for years because you have worked in other institutions. There is a strong passion for results and the pace moves at an alarming rate at times and not everyone suits that. We have gone through a period of rapid growth over the last couple of years and as a result, like any organisation, we have struggled to maintain clear lines of communication and have at times, gone overboard in creating tiresome processes for business improvement. 

A lot of people slate Hult as a place to work and as you would expect, this is generally people who don't fit the culture or whom have been released back into the community for poor performance. This is my way of addressing the imbalance.

pros: Great location, big open space office, well known school brand to work for
cons: People seem to be nice but they are all actually two-faced (they would rather tell the management team about your failures rather than say it straight to your face); management team cares only about sales but doesn't provide training (at least I didn't receive it, only my colleagues tried to help me out even though it wasn't their job)

job_title: Director of Enrollment in London, England
pros: Hult is honestly the best company I have ever worked for. It's young, flat (no hierarchy), entrepreneurial, international and a lot of fun. I've learned a lot about sales, customer service, maangement skills and different cultures over the past four years. As long as you're ambitious and enthusiastic, Hult can get you anywhere.
cons: Because of the entrepreneurial spirit that Hult has, decisions are being made fast. This causes the company to be fast paced and innovative, but can also mean things are a bit chaotic.

review_title: Gained a lot of experience, however was never valued or recognised
pros:
Work autonomously
Gain responsibility & experience
Nice working space
Lucrative business 
Nice people & students 
Good IT systems & hardware
cons:
The more work you take on, the more they gave you 
Any staff below Senior Management are worthless 
Evidently signs of nepotism and favouritism 
Low salaries & equality issues 
Maternity leave frowned upon 
Cheaper, younger staff replace middle managers 
No loyalty

pros: friendly working environment, young diverse colleagues, great location of campuses in London, fun place , after-work drinks and celebrations. The requirements are not very high and there are opportinities to move within a company
cons: low pay, swede style corporate structure which means that you are only valueble if you are a friend of someone from the company, noone cares about your qualifications.  The job is too relaxed. High turnover of employees

pros: Exposure to lots of different platforms and jobs outside of your role, some good perks - lots of events, trips for students you can join
cons: Expected to fulfil much more than in your contract. Expected to work longer hours often. Micro managed by senior management. Most senior management have very little people skills and care more about satisfaction statistics than anything else.

pros: The London campus has made great strides over the last few years to retain older employees through more flexible work plans, which was very appreciated by employees who also happen to be parents.  Hult management understands that flexibility and compassion lead to higher retention, and more committed, loyal, and hardworking employees.
cons: The school is exciting for people with a growth mindset who are able to embrace change - it's never boring!

review_title: Know what you are getting yourself into before applying
job_title: Director of Recruiting in London, England
pros: Travel perks are nice. Get to travel on the companies dime to some pretty nice destinations. Got to travel within my first month of working here and traveled several times thereafter.
cons:
Hult is forever RUINING what the world of higher education means today. This is  not a business school, but instead a for-profit sales and recruitment machine with pushy sales agents who work for low pay in long, demanding, and hostile hours. A well known practice for hiring and firing young talent who do not preform in reaching sales targets devised by weak management. Overall a very glossy product to the human eye, with rubbish and unethical practices which brand themselves as a place being the most international school in the world. They are very good and keen to invest in their sales and marketing budgets to make their brand most appealing, but do not realize people take notice of these efforts and it further weakens their degrees. 


-The most AGGRESSIVE recruitment and SALES operations in the university sector  (If you work for Hult, be prepared to sell. They are known for their hostile sales operations worldwide today. 
-Misleading advertised job postings which do not properly describe day to day job details (cold calling all day to sell students MBA, Masters, Bachelors degrees, and having to reach unrealistic sales targets. 
-Selling higher degrees with unethical means for admission and corrupt procedures 
-Overworked employees expected to do SO much in one working day, for way TOO little pay. 
-LONG sales hours to essentially SELL SELL SELL, and SELL more to students who cant afford programs and or would not be interested. 
-Admitting students who are not qualified or can barely speak English into all programs.  
-Being required to PUSH students to apply and submit application fees and tuition deposit (No other university in the world does this but Hult. It is the their method for growth. 
-Largest cash cow in the business. Not a real school, but simply a money making machine 
-Very secretive internal operations 

-The travel benefits are cool, however every week people are hired and fired, and people leave on their own after getting burnt out. They do a great job NOT having a human resources division, and hire the best young top international talent they can, use, abuse and get as much out of them as possible, see how long they can last if they don't already fire them, and then move  onto the next best thing. No investment or training for any employee, and honestly HULT does not give much attention to any of their employees. 

Not a real business school, with the most bizarre, hostile, and BI-polar  practices in the book. 

Know what your getting yourself into before applying and accepting a job here.

pros:
Nice offices
Staff trips 
Co-workers are nice
Not micromanaged (or managed at all)
Good social side if you want it
cons:
Contracts are unclear and subject to change
Hire and fire culture
Senior Managers job is to constantly squeeze as much as possible from their workers
No HR Department
Management have no morals
No consideration for work/life balance (7 days a week, 24 hours a day)
Constant pressure on staff who are treated like children
No pension or other benefits
No training given at any point
Free for all in office - fact that computer/mouses/staplers etc are routinely taken from colleagues desk gives indication of culture
Individuals set targets - no teamwork encouraged
Although HULT says they are entrepreneurial the minute someone tries to do that they are stopped.

job_title: Associate Director of Recruiting in Boothwyn, PA
pros: Hult mentality is work hard- play hard. If you like to work in a fast-moving, entrepreneurial environment where you get frequently challenged, then Hult is a great place to work. The managers do a lot to motivate their employees.
cons: If you prefer 9-5 jobs, then this is the wrong company. Working on weekends or overtime happens frequently in high season.

pros: My time at HULT International Business School was very successful. Positive colleagues. Ambitious students. Good working atmosphere. I can only recommend working at HULT International Business School.
cons: HULT International Business School is still in the process of expanding, which is why, there had been major changes to the organisation's workforce.

review_title: If for some reason they're hiring, do not apply to work for this company
pros: International environment, fast paced. I guess you could add the staff events that are organised are always fun, the new ED is also a big plus. Fingers crossed he doesn't change.
cons:
Senior management are a huge problem in the company, most staff are paid a disgusting amount but are over-worked. Hult will happily fire certain hard working and loyal working employees to make way for Hult family and friends, who will also inevitable be paid a much healthier salary that most. You might be lucky enough to work with unprofessional managers who slander their staff, relay private conversations and meetings they've had with the ED and Dean and share their departments salaries with other colleagues in their team.

If you work here expect to get pretty much nothing back, with hardly any opportunity to move up the ladder and unprofessionalism from the people you're supposed to learn from. You'll be surround by colleagues desperately trying to find other jobs and notices being handed in left right and centre.

Hult is on a slippery slope to having no staff left as they seldom replace the people leaving, consequently meaning other people are having more work dumped on to them. 

Overall they's no sincerity or integrity within this company, it's an awful and draining place to work no matter what department you work in.

pros: It's a young,international and dynamic environment. You feel motivated and included in the bigger picture. There are often dinners, events etc organized for the employees
cons: It's not really well paid. It's below the average. You're asked to work on Saturdays sometimes and in general you can be asked to be flexible and adapt to the company needs in terms of holidays, days off, etc

job_title: Associate Director of Recruiting in London, England
pros: The best thing about working for Hult is the good young atmosphere that you have. Most people are really friendly, although 26 years old on average...
cons: Low salary, lack of professionalism, worked very long hours and weekends, quite stressful due to really high targets, extremely high turnover

job_title: Director of Recruiting in London, England
pros: Good company to start a career in sales and get global exposure. Most offices have a great work atmosphere. If you constantly perform you can be compensated well, get promoted and have the option to work at other offices worldwide.
cons: Low staff retention. Very common to work on Saturdays and some Sundays, with no compensation. Minimum staff coaching. A lot of rotation in Senior Management team.

review_title: Fun and fast-moving, but lots of hard work
pros:
- Traveling around Europe / World
- Interesting job, if you really like working with people
- Good team environment
- Very flexible compared to other companies
- Modern office in good location
- Always compensates extra days worked
cons:
- It can be draining as it's long hours 
- Salaries are not great

pros: Working for Hult is an incredible experience where you get tons of responsibility from day one. You are pushed to developed while also getting the freedom to express ideas and projects that will help to improve the quickly growing business.
cons: It can sometimes be tough work and long hours, but it is worth it given the development you gain as a result.

pros: There are no good reasons
cons:
Everybody leaves. Ask for their turn over on the interview so you know. The minute you start in this company you start to hear about how much everyone hates it there and how everyone is looking for a job.
No growth
low pay
negativity
lack of motivation
lack of leadership
managers are involved with girls/boys on their team (as affairs or relationships)
I could go on and on...

pros: - Exciting. Talent magnets. Enablers. Fast career progression. Great people to work with. Great vision and mission. Positive impact on people and places.
cons: - Fast paced and the only constant is change - may not be suitable for everyone

review_title: Depends on what you are looking for!
job_title: Associate Director of Recruiting in London, England
pros:
Fun people, nice office, great location, constant entertaining of staff. 
Good place to improve your sales skills and event management skills.
cons:
If you are not into aggressive sales, you won't like it. High (and at times unrealistic) sales targets. 

Sometimes, we came to work on Saturdays and it was a norm.

pros: Good Education, costumer centric, nice people, flexible working
cons: terrible salaries, big difference between salaries, useless titles, more work that one can handle just to cut on roles, no career opportunities unless have a Masters degree

review_title: Lots of Opportunity, but it is what you make it.
job_title: Regional Marketing and Services Manager in London, England
pros: Lots of travel, great colleagues, lots of opportunity for advancement.
cons: Long working hours, flat Swede-style corporate structure means that those who play political games well and build a network often progress faster than those with the most skill.

pros: -Free lunch/frequent socials in the office
cons:
-Favouritism culture
-Lack of support in challenging situations
-Transactional approach to HR, high turn-over and poor communication of people leaving
-Management not accountable for their actions and some clearly lacking in basic skills to manage large teams/strategic vision to take the company where it needs to go.
-Low basic pay and poor commission scheme

review_title: international work environment but favoritism culture
pros: Travel and international work environment, great young colleagues; lunches and events
cons: Favoritism culture. The company chooses one person to report them gossips about the rest of the team. High turnover.

pros: Great culture full of international, young and dynamic colleagues. Office is well located nad very comfortable/design.
cons: Low work-to-reward ration, often having to work on weekends and long days and significantly high turnover in non-management roles.

pros: Well located. Most colleagues were friendly
cons: Low salary, job insecurity, they care more about PR than quality of education (they would bribe students into enrolling by giving them iPads).

review_title: Innovative, forward looking - can be 'every person for themselves'
pros: innovative ambitious fast-paced efficient hard working
cons: can be 'every person for themselves' - sink or swim.

pros: Flexibility, career development possibilities, multinational organisation, great company culture. You can add your own interests and strengths to your role.
cons: Being a private school, not the highest salaries in the market.

pros: Innovative. Hult provides always relevant content to prepare students to gain valuable skills and be job-ready at graduation
cons: None! Well, it’s not as well-known as it should be, sadly!

review_title: Good school with great opportunities to get culturally aware
pros: International, very good locations, amazing people and students
cons: Still new, not big recognition, needs to improve management team

pros: Great team environment, flexible hours, options to develop your career
cons: Salary is not the highest in the market for this position

pros: They offer career development paths. Great colleagues and work environment
cons: Offices are quite far away if you live in north london like me

pros: Free lunch, great training and friendly staff
cons: Low salaries, hard to move up

pros: Great company culture making you feel welcome.
